channel.title: Comments on: Should SQL Server Professionals Learn Oracle?
channel.description: A Technical Community for IT Professionals

item.title: By: David Forck (thirster42)
item.dc:creator: David Forck (thirster42)
item.description: awesome post ted. maybe when i get a little bit more horsepower in this machine i'll check out the virtual box install.
item.content:encoded: awesome post ted. maybe when i get a little bit more horsepower in this machine i’ll check out the virtual box install.

item.title: By: traingamer
item.dc:creator: traingamer
item.content:encoded:
My first client server project was an Access (version 1.1) front end to a Sybase (version 4.9.x) back end.
We had really primitive Sybase tools – we bought a tool called SQL Programmer (or SQL Miner or something – memory fails me) from a Canadian company to ease the pain of working with just a SQL command window.

I learned Sybase coding (Triggers, Stored Procedures, etc) from a Belgian who had never previously taught the class in English. Those were the days.

Each database server you learn makes you more valuable.

item.title: By: Rob Farley
item.dc:creator: Rob Farley
item.description: Can't you just log in as scott tiger any more?
item.content:encoded: Can’t you just log in as scott tiger any more?

item.title: By: SQLDenis
item.dc:creator: SQLDenis
item.description: You should strive to become a Polyglot, I remember reading in one of Ken Henderson's books that you should learn a new programming language every year. That is some good advice
item.content:encoded: You should strive to become a Polyglot, I remember reading in one of Ken Henderson’s books that you should learn a new programming language every year. That is some good advice

item.title: By: SQLDenis
item.dc:creator: SQLDenis
item.content:encoded:
How about Access and Excel?

How about NOT!

item.title: By: Doug B
item.dc:creator: Doug B
item.description: The converse is true as well. Oracle/Sybase/MySQL (don't forget this freebie as well) professionals should "cross train" as well. I've been in multi-platform shops off and on since 2001. Another factor to consider is platform consolidation. In a multi-platform environment invariably some XO will decide that supporting them has a negative TCO and very well consider eliminating one of them.
item.content:encoded: The converse is true as well. Oracle/Sybase/MySQL (don’t forget this freebie as well) professionals should “cross train” as well. I’ve been in multi-platform shops off and on since 2001. Another factor to consider is platform consolidation. In a multi-platform environment invariably some XO will decide that supporting them has a negative TCO and very well consider eliminating one of them.

item.title: By: Ted Krueger (onpnt)
item.dc:creator: Ted Krueger (onpnt)
item.content:encoded:
Don’t forget FoxPro. I know you love you some FoxPro ðŸ™‚

Thanks, Jeff. I’m going to bring it down tonight at home. Probably going to change the direction of the next post to that. Seems much more useful!

item.title: By: SQLDenis
item.dc:creator: SQLDenis
item.content:encoded:
Yes, SQL Server Pros should look at PostgreSQL, MySQL and even at the NoSQL solutions like MongoDB, RavenDB, Cassandra and others

Me….I also have to deal with Sybase, Sybase IQ and their Replication Server…after working with Sybase tools I will never say anything bad about the SQL Server tooling

item.title: By: SQLDenis
item.dc:creator: SQLDenis
item.content:encoded:
Jeff,

Thanks for the link, I have been using Virtual Box for a long time and this will make messing around with Oracle much easier
